yeah, repeatable read is pretty serious.
but assuming your transactions are per-request, I doubt you'd run into a real issue..
but.. RR has locking overhead that's usually not worthwhile.
Read Uncommitted, Read Committed, Repeatable Read, and Serialized (or something) are your choices. I tend to favor Read Committed by default

working without limit
so... either cursor was pointing at the wrong db that whole time, or is there some sort of query caching enabled?
did you have a single tx open the whole time and repeatable read (the very odd inno default) ?
so updates at the shell were tx per statement, and your shell tx would ignore
yes
right.. but if your shell opened a tx before the update.. and repeatable read is your iso level (default on inno).. AND you queried before the update was done..
unless you issue a BEGIN in the shell... it's a transaction per statement.. so the isolation level is effectively meaningless.
so queries at the shell would show the result.. but repeated queries in a tx from the django console wouldn't
in general, I prefer to us the isolation level Read Committed and upgrade to RR on a case-by-case basis...
so should I expect our wsgi app to face this issue?
but there are mysql replication reasons to use RR apparently
well.. if you have a long running request that queries more than once, you could.
